chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text:
$a)$ First, we have to find out the return on equity of normal expansion condition which we denote with $RN$, where the income $I$ is $\$29,000$ and the equity value $EV$ is $185,000$

$$\begin{align*}
RN&=\frac{I}{EV}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000}{185,000}\\[12pt]
&=0.1567\\[7pt]&=15.67\%
\end{align*}$$

So, the return on equity of nominal expansion is $\boxed{15.67\%}$

We have to find out the return on equity of expansion economic condition which we denote with $RE$, where the income $I$ is $\$29,000$, equity value $EV$ is $185,000$ and the increase rate $IR$ is $30\%$

$$\begin{align*}
RE&=\frac{I \times (1+IR)}{EV}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times (1+30\%)}{185,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times (1+0.3)}{185,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times 1.3}{185,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{37,700}{185,000}\\[12pt]
&=0.2037\\[7pt]
&=20.37\%
\end{align*}$$

So, the return on equity of expansion economic condition is $\boxed{20.37\%}$

We have to find out the return on equity of recession economic condition which we denote with $RR$, where the income $I$ is $\$29,000$, equity value $EV$ is $185,000$ and the decrease rate $DR$ is $40\%$

$$\begin{align*}
RE&=\frac{I \times (1-DR)}{EV}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times (1-40\%)}{185,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times (1-0.4)}{185,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times 0.6}{185,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{17,400}{185,000}\\[12pt]
&=0.0940\\[7pt]
&=9.40\%
\end{align*}$$

So, the return on equity of recession economic condition is $\boxed{9.40\%}$

We have to find out the actual percentage change in return on equity which we denote with $PR$, where the return on equity of expansion economic $RE$ is $20.37\%$, and the return on equity of nominal economic are $RN$ is $15.67\%$

$$\begin{align*} PR&=\frac{RE-RN}{RN}\\[12pt] &=\frac{20.37\%-15.67\%}{15.67\%}\\[12pt]&=\frac{0.2037-0.1567}{0.1567}\\[12pt] &=\frac{0.047}{0.1567}\\[12pt] &=0.2999\\[7pt] &=29.99\% \end{align*}$$
 

So, the actual percentage change in return on equity is $\boxed{29.99\%}$
â€‹

We have to find out the actual percentage change in return on equity from nominal to recession which we denote with $PR$, where the return on equity of recession economic $R$ is $9.40\%$, and the return on equity of nominal economic are $RN$ is $15.67\%$

$$\begin{align*} PR&=\frac{R-RN}{RN}\\[12pt] &=\frac{9.40\%-15.67\%}{15.67\%}\\[12pt]&=\frac{0.094-0.1567}{0.1567}\\[12pt] &=\frac{-0.0627}{0.1567}\\[12pt] &=-0.4001\\[7pt] &=-40.01\% \end{align*}$$
 

So, the actual percentage change in return on equity is $\boxed{-40.01\%}$

$b)$ Second, we have to find out the new value of the firm under restructuring which we denote with $NV$, where the the market value $MV$ is $185,000$  and the issued debt $ID$ is $65,000$

$$\begin{align*}
NV&=MV - ID\\[7pt]
&=185,000-65,000\\[7pt]
&=\$120,000
\end{align*}$$

So, the new value of the firm under restructuring is $\boxed{\$120,000}$

We have to find out the actual interest expenses which we denote with $AE$, where the interest rate $IR$ is $7\%$ and the issued debt $ID$ is $65,000$

$$\begin{align*}
AE&=IR \times IS\\[7pt]
&=7\% \times 65,000\\[7pt]
&=0.07 \times 65,000\\[7pt]
&=4,550
\end{align*}$$

So, the actual interest expenses is $\boxed{\$4,500}$

We have to find out the return on equity under a normal economy which we denote with $RN$, where the income $I$ is $29,000$, actual interest expenses $AE$ is $4,500$ and the new equity $NE$ is $120,000$

$$\begin{align*}
RN&=\frac{I-AE}{NE}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000-4,500}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{24,450}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=0.2037\\[7pt]
&=20.37\%
\end{align*}$$

So, the return on equity under a normal economy $\boxed{20.37\%}$

We have to find out the return on equity under expansion economic condition which we denote with $RE$, where the income $I$ is $29,000$, Increase rate $IR$ is $30\%$, actual interest expenses $AE$ is $4,550$ and the new equity $NE$ is $120,000$

$$\begin{align*}

RE&=\frac{I \times (1+IR) - AE}{NE}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times (1+30\%) - 4,550}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times (1+0.3) - 4,550}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times 1.3 - 4,550}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{37,700 - 4,550}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{33,150}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=0.2762\\[7pt]
&=27.62\%
\end{align*}$$

So, return on equity under expansion economic condition is $\boxed{27.62\%}$

We have to find out the return on equity under recession economic condition which we denote with $RER$, where the income $I$ is $29,000$, decrease rate $DR$ is $40\%$, actual interest expenses $AE$ is $4,550$ and the new equity $NE$ is $120,000$

$$\begin{align*}

RER&=\frac{I \times (1+DR) - AE}{NE}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times (1+40\%) - 4,550}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times (1-0.4) - 4,550}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times 0.6 - 4,550}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{17,400 - 4,550}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{12,850}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=0.1070\\[7pt]
&=10.70\%
\end{align*}$$

So, return on equity under recession economic condition is $\boxed{10.70\%}$

We have to find a percentage change in return on equity from normal to expansion condition which we denote with  $PE$, where the return on equity under expansion economic condition $RE$ is $27.62\%$ and the return on equity under a normal economy $RN$ is $20.37\%$

$$\begin{align*}
PE&=\frac{RE-RN}{RN}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{27.62\%-20.37\%}{20.37\%}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{0.2762-0.2037}{0.2037}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{0.0725}{0.2037}\\[12pt]
&=0.3559\\[7pt]
&=35.59\%
\end{align*}$$

So, the percentage change in return on equity from normal to expansion condition $\boxed{35.59\%}$

We have to find a percentage change in return on equity from normal to recession condition which we denote with  $PR$, where the return on equity under recession economic condition $RER$ is $10.70\%$ and the return on equity under a normal economy $RN$ is $20.37\%$

$$\begin{align*}
PR&=\frac{RER-RN}{RN}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{10.70\%-20.37\%}{20.37\%}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{0.1070-0.2037}{0.2037}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{-0.0967}{0.2037}\\[12pt]
&=-0.4747\\[7pt]
&=-47.47\%
\end{align*}$$

So, the percentage change in return on equity from normal to recession condition $\boxed{-47.47\%}$

$c)$ Third, we have to find out the return on equity under normal economic condition which we denote with $RN$, where the income $I$ is $29,000$, actual interest expenses $AE$ is $4,550$, tax rate $TR$ is $21\%$ and the new equity $NE$ is $120,000$

$$\begin{align*}
RN&=\frac{I - AE \times (1-TR)}{NE}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 - 4,550 \times (1-21\%)}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 - 4,550 \times (1-0.21)}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 - 4,550 \times 0.79}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{24,450\times 0.79}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{19315.5}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=0.1609\\[7pt]
&=16.09\%

\end{align*}$$

So, the  return on equity under normal economic conditions is $\boxed{16.09\%}$

We have to find out the return on equity under expansion economic condition which we denote with $RE$, where the income $I$ is $29,000$, increase rate $IR$ is $0.3$, actual interest expenses $AE$ is $4,550$, tax rate $TR$ is $21\%$ and the new equity $NE$ is $120,000$

$$\begin{align*}
RE&=\frac{I \times (1+ IR) -AE\times (1-TR)}{NE}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times (1+0.3) - 4,550 \times(1-21\%)}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times 1.3 - 4,550 \times (1-0.21)}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{37,700- 4,550 \times0.79}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{26188.5}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=0.2182\\[7pt]
&=21.82\%

\end{align*}$$

So, the  return on equity under expansion economic conditions is $\boxed{21.82\%}$

We have to find out the return on equity under recession economic condition which we denote with $RER$, where the income $I$ is $29,000$, decrease rate $DR$ is $0.4$, actual interest expenses $AE$ is $4,550$, tax rate $TR$ is $21\%$ and the new equity $NE$ is $120,000$

$$\begin{align*}
RER&=\frac{I \times (1- DR) -AE\times (1-TR)}{NE}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times (1-0.4) - 4,550 \times (1-21\%)}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{29,000 \times 0.6 - 4,550 \times (1-0.21)}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{17,400- 4,550 \times  0.79}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{10151.5}{120,000}\\[12pt]
&=0.0845\\[7pt]
&=8.45\%

\end{align*}$$

So, the  return on equity under recession economic conditions is $\boxed{8.45\%}$

We have to find a percentage change in return on equity from normal to expansion condition which we denote with  $PE$, where the return on equity under expansion economic condition $RE$ is $21.82\%$ and the return on equity under a normal economy $RN$ is $16.09\%$

$$\begin{align*}
PE&=\frac{RE-RN}{RN}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{21.82\%-16.09\%}{16.09\%}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{0.2182-0.1609}{0.1609}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{0.0573}{0.1609}\\[12pt]
&=0.3561\\[7pt]
&=35.61\%
\end{align*}$$

So, the percentage change in return on equity from normal to expansion condition $\boxed{35.61\%}$

We have to find a percentage change in return on equity from normal to recession condition which we denote with  $PR$, where the return on equity under recession economic condition $RER$ is $8.45\%$ and the return on equity under a normal economy $RN$ is $16.09\%$

$$\begin{align*}
PR&=\frac{RER-RN}{RN}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{8.45\%-16.09\%}{16.09\%}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{0.0845-0.1609}{0.1609}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{-0.0764}{0.1609}\\[12pt]
&=-0.4748\\[7pt]
&=-47.48\%
\end{align*}$$

So, the percentage change in return on equity from normal to recession condition $\boxed{-47.48\%}$
